senses.de: Something that you must do because of a rule or a law.
senses.ex: Wearing a helmet while riding a bike is mandatory in many countries.

Tips.title: Beyond Laws
Tips.description: Mandatory isn't used only for laws but for rules in organizations, schools, or clubs.
Tips.example: Attendance is mandatory for all members at the club meetings.

Tips.title: Safety Related
Tips.description: 'Mandatory' is often used in safety contexts to mean 'necessary for safety'.
Tips.example: It's mandatory to wash your hands before serving food.

Tips.title: Not Optional
Tips.description: When something is mandatory, you cannot choose whether to follow it or not.
Tips.example: Completing this course is mandatory for graduation.

senses.de: Relating to a command or an authoritative instruction.
senses.ex: The mandatory meeting will cover new company policies.

Tips.title: Authority Implication
Tips.description: Mandatory actions are usually set and enforced by someone in power, like a boss or leader.
Tips.example: The manager made it mandatory to report progress weekly.

Tips.title: Expect Compliance
Tips.description: When something is mandatory, failure to comply could lead to penalties or consequences.
Tips.example: Mandatory evacuation orders were issued before the storm hit.

Tips.title: Prompt Action
Tips.description: Mandatory often means action is required immediately or within a given timeframe.
Tips.example: Completing an employee survey by Friday is mandatory.

senses.de: In law, relating to a decision made by a court or a judge.
senses.ex: Under mandatory sentencing, the judge must impose a fixed sentence.

Tips.title: Legal Requirement
Tips.description: In legal contexts, 'mandatory' means it's ordered by court and there's no room for discretion.
Tips.example: The court issued a mandatory injunction against the company.

Tips.title: Fixed Sentencing
Tips.description: 'Mandatory sentencing' refers to a court decision with predetermined penalties.
Tips.example: The law requires mandatory life sentencing for such offenses.

Tips.title: No Judge's Liberty
Tips.description: Under mandatory laws, judges can't use their personal judgment to alter the punishment.
Tips.example: With mandatory sentencing, the judge couldn't reduce the time served.

Compulsory.wordDefinition:
Both words, compulsory and mandatory, mean "required" but they have slightly different connotations. Compulsory means something that is required by law or authority, while mandatory means something that is required because it is essential or necessary.

For example, wearing a helmet when riding a bike is compulsory in some places because it is required by law, but taking a shower before going to school is not compulsory even though it may be necessary for personal hygiene.

Compulsory is usually used when something is required by authority or law, while mandatory is used when something is essential or necessary.

Demand.wordDefinition:
Demand means that you want something, but it's not necessary that you get it. For example, you might demand a big birthday party, but your parents might not be able to afford it.

Demand is a request while mandatory is a requirement.

Enforce.wordDefinition:
Enforce means to make sure that rules or laws are being followed and that punishments are given out if they are not followed.

For example, a police officer might enforce traffic laws by giving tickets to people who break them.

Enforce and mandatory are related because enforcing a law or rule is one way to make it mandatory.

However, something can be mandatory without necessarily being enforced. For example, it might be mandatory for a company to have a certain kind of safety equipment on hand, but if no one checks to make sure they have it, it might not be enforced.

Essential.wordDefinition:
Essential means something that is very important or necessary, but there may be exceptions where it is not required. For example, water is essential for survival but not everyone needs the same amount of water.

Essential is used in situations where something is important or necessary but may vary depending on the circumstances. Mandatory is used in situations where something is required by law or rules and must be followed without exception.

Imperative.wordDefinition:
Imperative means something that is very important and should be done right away.

It is often used to describe tasks or actions that are necessary for a particular situation or goal. For example, it is imperative to evacuate during a natural disaster to ensure your safety.

Imperative means something that is urgent and important to achieve a particular goal, while mandatory means something that is required by law or rules.

Necessary.wordDefinition:
Mandatory means required or ordered by an authority, while the word necessary means needed or required for a specific purpose.

For example, wearing a helmet while riding a bike may be mandatory in some cities, which means it is required by law. On the other hand, having a pencil and paper while taking an exam may be necessary to complete the task at hand.

Mandatory describes something that is required by authority, while necessary describes something that is needed to accomplish a goal or task.

Obligatory.wordDefinition:
Both mandatory and obligatory mean that something is required or necessary.

However, mandatory carries a connotation that the requirement is imposed by an authority or rule, while obligatory carries a connotation that the requirement is a moral or ethical duty.

For example, wearing a uniform to school may be mandatory because there is a school rule requiring it. On the other hand, being honest and truthful is obligatory because it is a moral duty to be truthful to others.

Mandatory is often used in formal or legal contexts, while obligatory is often used in moral or philosophical discussions.

Require.wordDefinition:
Mandatory means something that must be done or followed as a requirement, without exception. It implies that there is a law, rule, or regulation that requires it.

For example, wearing a seatbelt in the car is mandatory because it is required by law.

Require means something that is necessary or needed.

It may be mandatory in some cases, but not always. For example, a job may require a certain level of education or experience, but it is not mandatory by law.

Mandatory is a stronger word that implies legal obligation, while require is a more general word that can be used in different situations.
